THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 14, 1930

Vol. XXXIV, No. 30

TO TAKE PICTURES
FOR HULLABALOO
The official photographer
for the 1930 Hullabaloo is expected to be on the campus
within the next two weeks; so
all Seniors who wish their
photographs to appear in the
year book, and have not as yet
had them taken, will please
drop a note into George Gettemuller's P. 0. Box No. 350.
This applies to those who are
dissastified with their present
photographs as well as those
a c t iv ities and fraternities
whose pictures have not as yet
been taken.

HOPKINS ADOPTS MOONLIGHT DANCES
DUE TO ENERGETIC GATE-CRASHER
When the regular Saturday night
dances were held in the C. E. Flail
there was no difficulty whatever in
crashing the gate. One could quite
readily go from the M. E. to C. E.
building through the tunnel and
come out and up to the hall without
trouble.

JUNIOR BANQUET
TO BE FORMAL
It has been decided by the
Juni o r Banquet Committee
that the class of 1931 will hold
a formal banquet this year.
No decision has been reached
as to the date, location or entertainment. It is planned to
hold the banquet at some hotel
in Baltimore. Belmont Towbin, chairman of the committee, would like to be informed
of any objections to the above
plan, and is open to all suggestions.
Invitations to the banquet
will be sent to the President
of the University, the Dean
of the College of Arts and
Sciences, and other officials.
Last year the class of 1931
held a traditional informal
type of banquet and the committee desires that the affair
be of an entirely different
nature this spring.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 14, 1930

BARNSTORMERS DECIDE TO USE GIRLS FOR
FEMININE ROLES AFTER PRESENT SEASON
The recent Barnstormer productions were no doubt likely to produce a bit of skepticism as to the
future employment of male interpretation of female roles. Moreover this skepticism was no doubt
legally conceived, for it seems that
the Barnstormers are actually about
t amputate that leg of their dramatic anatomy in the use of girls in the
female parts of their forthcoming
production, "If I were King."
Whether or not the surgical dicctions emanated from exterior or
interior sources, is not our pleasure
to discuss at this time. But the fact
mains that it is a gesture so
sagacious that it is quite alien to
the usual practices of the various
departments of Hopkins' student
activities. It represents a willingness
to entertain beneficial innovation no
matter how radical it may be. Drastis renovations could well be made
in most any student activity on the
campus from the mild instance of
the Debating Club to the flagrant
one of the Blue Jay. Yet as far as
may be seen the general attitude is
one that has maintained a noxious
indifference to defects most. gross
in their conspicuity. Hence, the
Blue Jay, the Y. M. C. A., the football team, the swimming team,
the Debating Club and others, perhaps, are involved in a turmoil too
much like clean-cut comedy to be
able to guard against a future
abolishment of all activities that
must surely come at the present
pace.
The dramatic institution that the

Barnstormer's propose to displace
is one of not recent antiquation.
When the American Coquette decided to lay aside her bustle and go
in for college and emancipation, the
college female impersonator began
to be regarded not only as counterfeit, but as immoral. College boys
seemed to prefer the promising
bulge of the coed to the unconvincing pads of the impersonator. Kissing a rough beard on play night,
college heroes discovered, was nothing like necking an affable coed
during rehearsals. And so the custom that has persisted at Hopkins
and several colleges has been placed
among the moth balls by the dramatic cliques of. Most others.
Tentatively, the Barnstormers
propose to recruit actresses from the
College for Teachers. This, however, is a singularly dubious task
they have set for themselves. As
yet, we have failed to encounter a
coed from the Teachers' College
who didn't look just like a coed from
the Teachers' College. Hopkins obviously has not been endowed with
beautiful girls nor is there any evidence that it has or will give birth
to passable actresses.
One can always appreciate a
handsome girl who is a good
actress. One can even appreciate a
handsome girl who isn't a good actress. Girls, however, who have
neither of these qualities should not
become actresses unless they can
also become the mistress of the local dramatic critic.
H.L.F.

CALL MADE FOR
BALLET DANCERS
The Barnstormers are sending out a call for 16 men to
take part in a ballet dance in
the 1930 production. The play
to be given this year is McCarthy's "If I Were King."
"Pops" Swindell, the Barnstormers coach, wishes to
stage a ballet dance at one
part of the play. There will be
eight women and eight men.
To take one of the women's
part it is not necessary to be
effeminate looking. The steps
of the dance will be simple
and not difficult to learn.
Anyone interested in getting one of these parts, will
please report tomorrow afternoon, Saturday at 2.30 o'clock
at the Barn.

This afternoon at 1 p. m. Dr. H.
Kugler will address a meeting of
the Liberal Club in Room C. second
floor, Levering Hall. Dr. Kugler, is
a well-known German student, and
at the present time is studying here
at Homewood. Dr. Kugler has already received his Ph.D. in both
Economics and Chemistry. The
speaker who is well acquainted with
the political situation in Germany
today, has chosen as his topic "German Political Leaders of Today."

A shakedown test, a rescue,
and a hundred thrills
SCORE of carefree Coast Guard
sailors, and with them a Westing..
houseman from the Boston Office,
headed in a "bum boat" for the cutter
Chelan peacefully at anchor in the
harbor of Hamilton, Bermuda Islands.
It had been an exciting shakedown
test-cruise. The Westinghouse turbine
generator, motor and condensers had
functioned perfectly, the sea had yielded up its bag of tricks, the Bermudas
had fascinated every soul. And soon
they would be bound for home.
But fate held new experiences in store.
Five hundred miles off the Azores, the
Newport,New York State training ship,
had lost her propeller. The Chelan was
called to the rescue. And with her, of
course, went the Westinghouse man.

completed, is equipped with Westinghouse
turbine electric drive.

Three days at top speed on tropical
waters, the excitement of rescuing a
helpless crew, twelve days at a lazy
towing speed, men overboard and a rescue at sea—thrills like those come to
many Westinghouse men in line with
their work at electrifying the world.
For Westinghouse, in a commanding
position in electrical development,enters
every field of industry where electricity
is or may be employed. And Westinghouse men get a taste of every brand
of human activity.

type of banquet and the committee desires that the affair
be of an entirely different
nature this spring.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 14, 1930
To Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.
COTILLION CLUB
ANNOUNCES DANCE
The Cotillion Board wishes
to announce that it will hold
a dance in Levering Hall tomorrow night from 9 'til 12.
The price of admission will
be $1.00 stag or couple. The
music will be furnished by the
usual orchestra and, as at past
Saturday night dances, a door
prize will be given.
These dances have been
rather will attended this year
and the Board in charge of
the dances, hopes that the students will continue to put in
their appearance and make the
affairs a success.

COLLEGE AFFAIRS

Dear Sir:
What's the cause of "F.G.S.'s"
dyspeptic tirade against graduate
students? Did one of his instructors
fail to credit him with a passing
mark or did he just want to break
into print? Poor boy, he might as
well try to stop Niagara Falls by
whistling at it. "Ben" in his poorest days was more vitrolic. I humbly suggest that F.G.S. look into
the NEWS-LETTER files Of last year
and learn what destructive criticism
can really achieve.
With sympathetic encouragement.
Grotius.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 14, 1930

BARNSTORMERS DECIDE TO USE GIRLS FOR
FEMININE ROLES AFTER PRESENT SEASON
The recent Barnstormer productions were no doubt likely to produce a bit of skepticism as to the
future employment of male interpretation of female roles. Moreover this skepticism was no doubt
legally conceived, for it seems that
the Barnstormers are actually about
t amputate that leg of their dramatic anatomy in the use of girls in the
female parts of their forthcoming
production, "If I were King."
Whether or not the surgical dicctions emanated from exterior or
interior sources, is not our pleasure
to discuss at this time. But the fact
mains that it is a gesture so
sagacious that it is quite alien to
the usual practices of the various
departments of Hopkins' student
activities. It represents a willingness
to entertain beneficial innovation no
matter how radical it may be. Drastis renovations could well be made
in most any student activity on the
campus from the mild instance of
the Debating Club to the flagrant
one of the Blue Jay. Yet as far as
may be seen the general attitude is
one that has maintained a noxious
indifference to defects most. gross
in their conspicuity. Hence, the
Blue Jay, the Y. M. C. A., the football team, the swimming team,
the Debating Club and others, perhaps, are involved in a turmoil too
much like clean-cut comedy to be
able to guard against a future
abolishment of all activities that
must surely come at the present
pace.
The dramatic institution that the

Barnstormer's propose to displace
is one of not recent antiquation.
When the American Coquette decided to lay aside her bustle and go
in for college and emancipation, the
college female impersonator began
to be regarded not only as counterfeit, but as immoral. College boys
seemed to prefer the promising
bulge of the coed to the unconvincing pads of the impersonator. Kissing a rough beard on play night,
college heroes discovered, was nothing like necking an affable coed
during rehearsals. And so the custom that has persisted at Hopkins
and several colleges has been placed
among the moth balls by the dramatic cliques of. Most others.
Tentatively, the Barnstormers
propose to recruit actresses from the
College for Teachers. This, however, is a singularly dubious task
they have set for themselves. As
yet, we have failed to encounter a
coed from the Teachers' College
who didn't look just like a coed from
the Teachers' College. Hopkins obviously has not been endowed with
beautiful girls nor is there any evidence that it has or will give birth
to passable actresses.
One can always appreciate a
handsome girl who is a good
actress. One can even appreciate a
handsome girl who isn't a good actress. Girls, however, who have
neither of these qualities should not
become actresses unless they can
also become the mistress of the local dramatic critic.
H.L.F.

CALL MADE FOR
BALLET DANCERS
The Barnstormers are sending out a call for 16 men to
take part in a ballet dance in
the 1930 production. The play
to be given this year is McCarthy's "If I Were King."
"Pops" Swindell, the Barnstormers coach, wishes to
stage a ballet dance at one
part of the play. There will be
eight women and eight men.
To take one of the women's
part it is not necessary to be
effeminate looking. The steps
of the dance will be simple
and not difficult to learn.
Anyone interested in getting one of these parts, will
please report tomorrow afternoon, Saturday at 2.30 o'clock
at the Barn.

This afternoon at 1 p. m. Dr. H.
Kugler will address a meeting of
the Liberal Club in Room C. second
floor, Levering Hall. Dr. Kugler, is
a well-known German student, and
at the present time is studying here
at Homewood. Dr. Kugler has already received his Ph.D. in both
Economics and Chemistry. The
speaker who is well acquainted with
the political situation in Germany
today, has chosen as his topic "German Political Leaders of Today."

A shakedown test, a rescue,
and a hundred thrills
SCORE of carefree Coast Guard
sailors, and with them a Westing..
houseman from the Boston Office,
headed in a "bum boat" for the cutter
Chelan peacefully at anchor in the
harbor of Hamilton, Bermuda Islands.
It had been an exciting shakedown
test-cruise. The Westinghouse turbine
generator, motor and condensers had
functioned perfectly, the sea had yielded up its bag of tricks, the Bermudas
had fascinated every soul. And soon
they would be bound for home.
But fate held new experiences in store.
Five hundred miles off the Azores, the
Newport,New York State training ship,
had lost her propeller. The Chelan was
called to the rescue. And with her, of
course, went the Westinghouse man.

The Chelan, like four other Coast Guard Cutters recently
completed, is equipped with Westinghouse
turbine electric drive.

Three days at top speed on tropical
waters, the excitement of rescuing a
helpless crew, twelve days at a lazy
towing speed, men overboard and a rescue at sea—thrills like those come to
many Westinghouse men in line with
their work at electrifying the world.
For Westinghouse, in a commanding
position in electrical development,enters
every field of industry where electricity
is or may be employed. And Westinghouse men get a taste of every brand
of human activity.
